summary: A video tutorial providing instructions on how to access the Dark Web using a VPN and Tor Browser, while emphasizing user responsibility and ethical considerations.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer desktop screen displaying various icons and a large Android logo in the center. The taskbar at the bottom shows the time as 4:08 PM and the date as 11/16/2017. The cursor moves to the PureVPN icon, opening a window that shows a VPN connection status with options like 'Private Browsing,' 'Secure Connection,' and 'DNS Protection,' all enabled, and the location set to Stockholm, Sweden. The cursor clicks the 'Disconnect' button, and the window closes. The scene transitions to a blue and white animated logo with the text '160' and '160 VPN' in a futuristic style. The video then returns to the desktop, where the PureVPN window reopens, showing the same VPN connection status. The cursor clicks the 'Disconnect' button again, and the window closes. The final scene shows the DuckDuckGo logo on a white background, indicating a search engine page. The video concludes with the cursor moving towards the DuckDuckGo logo, suggesting an interaction with the search engine.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip opens with a brief musical introduction featuring upbeat synth rhythms, transitioning into a speaker introducing a how-to guide for accessing the dark web. They express caution, emphasizing the need for a VPN and stating that they're currently using PureVPN. They clearly state that this is done at the user's own risk and caution against exploring what may be found on the dark web. The clip concludes with a return of the upbeat synth music.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer screen displaying a web browser open to the DuckDuckGo search engine, where the user has typed "torproject.org" into the search bar. The search results show links to the Tor Project's website, with the first link highlighted. The user clicks on the highlighted link, and the browser navigates to the Tor Project's homepage, which features a purple banner with the text "Protecting Journalists, Whistleblowers, & Activists Since 2006" and a green "Donate Now!" button. The homepage also includes sections titled "Anonymity Online," "What is Tor?," and "Why Anonymity Matters," along with a download button for the Tor Browser. The user then clicks on the download button, leading to a new page with a yellow warning box stating, "Want Tor to really work? You'll need to change some of your settings. Some things won't work exactly as you used to use them, but the rest of the Internet will be safer." Below the warning, there is a section for downloading the Tor Browser for Windows, with a "Download" button and a "Donate" button. The video concludes with the user still on the download page, with the download button highlighted, indicating the user's intention to proceed with the download.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker describing how to access the Tor browser to browse the dark web. He explains that Tor stands for the "onion router," and dark websites are called ".onion" sites. He then instructs to download the browser from the website, pointing out the site's claim that it provides everything needed for safe browsing. Concurrently with this, there is background music of an electronic style that sounds ambient and somewhat futuristic.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying the download page for the Tor Browser for Windows. The page features a prominent purple download button labeled "DOWNLOAD Tor Browser" and a yellow "DONATE" button. A warning message in a yellow box at the top of the page reads, "Want Tor to really work? You need to change some of your settings. Some things won't work exactly as you used to use the full list of." The page also includes a link to learn more about the browser and a section for users who do not use Windows, offering downloads for Mac or Linux. The download progress bar at the bottom of the screen shows the file "torbrowser-install...exe" being downloaded, with the progress updating in real-time. The taskbar at the bottom of the screen displays various icons, including the Windows Start button, a search bar, and several application icons. The video captures the process of downloading the Tor Browser, highlighting the user interface and download progress.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker discussing the dark web. He states a "common misconception" is that it's dangerous, but that it's actually safe a lot of the time depending on where you go. He gives the example of visiting websites with illegal activity, and states "if you're looking for trouble." He finishes by saying that if you seek information without causing trouble, you won't find any. Soft music, which can be described as ambient, plays in the background, contributing to the mood.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer screen displaying the Tor Browser download page for Windows, featuring a prominent purple download button and a warning message about the file's origin. The scene transitions to a desktop with various icons, including a running VPN client window showing security features and a 'Disconnect' button. The focus then shifts to an Android mascot icon with a language selection dialog box, where the user selects 'English' and proceeds to the Tor Browser installation setup. The setup window shows the destination folder as 'C:\Users\achmad\Desktop\Tor Browser' and the required space of 145.4MB, with the user clicking 'Install.' The installation process is shown with a progress bar indicating the extraction of 'xul.dll' at 15%, 30%, and 50%. The video concludes with the installation window still open, displaying the progress bar at 50% and the 'Show details' button visible.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with speech, where a male speaker describes a download process as "pretty quick" and guides the listener to run the downloaded file. He notes that Norton identifies it as safe and then proceeds to select English. Following this, he mentions accepting the default installation location, emphasizing that it's a "fairly quick install." He concludes by stating that the Tor browser will soon be ready, allowing for anonymous browsing. Throughout this speech, there's background music playing, characterized as calm and mysterious, possibly designed to create a sense of intrigue or focus.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases the installation process of the Tor Browser on a computer. It begins with a progress window titled "Tor Browser Setup" indicating that the installation is in progress, with a message instructing the user to wait while the browser is being installed. The progress bar shows the extraction of various files, including "xul.dll," "geoip6," "meek-client.exe," "omni.jar," and "en-US.dic," with the percentage of completion increasing for each file. The user interface includes a "Show details" button and options for "Back," "Next," and "Cancel" at the bottom. The installation process continues until the final stage, where a completion window appears with the message "Tor Browser has been installed on your computer." The user is prompted to click "Finish" to close the wizard, with options to "Run Tor Browser" and "Add Start Menu & Desktop shortcuts" checked. The video concludes with the user clicking the "Finish" button, indicating the successful completion of the installation.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing VPNs, mentioning that while he has one, it isn't always necessary. He explains that the purpose of the Tor browser is to be anonymous, connecting to several nodes before reaching the desired website. The speaker uses a conversational tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer desktop featuring a large Android logo at the center, surrounded by various application icons such as 'Recycle Bin,' 'Calculator,' 'Google Chrome,' 'Music Folder,' 'iTunes,' 'GDB Studio,' 'Check Security,' 'Get Top Easycut,' 'CBT Tools,' 'PowerShell,' and 'Far Browser.' The taskbar at the bottom shows the time as 4:03 PM and the date as 11/16/2007. The cursor moves to the 'Tor Browser' icon, right-clicks, and selects 'Open,' launching the Tor Browser window. The browser opens to the Tor Project's welcome page, displaying a message about protecting privacy and a 'Donate Now' button. The cursor clicks 'Test Tor Network Settings,' and the page updates to show a green onion logo with a message confirming the browser is configured to use Tor. The cursor then clicks 'Donate to Support Tor.' The scene transitions to a new window showing the Tor Browser's settings, including options like 'Advanced Security Features,' 'DNS Protection,' and 'IPv6 Protection,' with the location set to Stockholm, Sweden. The cursor clicks 'Disconnect,' and the video concludes with the Tor Browser window closed, returning to the desktop view with the Android logo and application icons.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker indicating something is finished and suggesting to double-click a "Tor browser" icon. The speaker continues in a conversational tone, noting Tor's slower speed due to its use of multiple nodes. Then, the Tor browser is welcomed. The speaker then proceeds to "test the tour network settings", with an affirmation that it's configured correctly. The speaker also mentions an IP address difference from a VPN. All of this occurs with ambient droning or static sounds in the background throughout.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer screen displaying a webpage that confirms the browser is configured to use Tor, with the IP address 197.231.221.211 visible. The page features a green onion logo and a blue button labeled "Donate to Support Tor." The user navigates to DuckDuckGo, a privacy-focused search engine, and types "best onion sites" into the search bar. The search results page appears, showing various links related to onion sites, with the DuckDuckGo logo and a privacy-focused message visible. The user scrolls through the search results, which include articles and lists about onion sites, with the DuckDuckGo interface and search bar remaining visible throughout. The video concludes with the user still viewing the search results page, highlighting the privacy-focused nature of the search engine and the Tor browser.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with one male speaker setting the scene, stating, "Alright, so first thing we'll do is we'll go to a surface web website." He discusses searching for ".onion" sites via a search engine, clarifying that "it's a search engine that doesn't track you." He states that he's "just going to do a quick search for best onion sites." While the speaker is talking, light, rhythmic music plays in the background. The speaker's tone is calm and descriptive. After he finishes talking, the music continues without speech.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a web browser with the ExpressVPN website open. The page features a blog post titled "9 must-see onion sites from the depths of the dark web," authored by Kevin on September 15, 2016. The article discusses the anonymity of onion sites and their significance in the dark web. The first section of the article highlights ProPublica, a Pulitzer-winning online publication, with a link to their onion site. The video then transitions to a screenshot of the ProPublica website, showcasing its homepage with a blue header and a featured article titled "Killing the Colorado." The next section of the article introduces Facebook's onion site, with a link provided. The video concludes with a screenshot of the Facebook login page, displaying the ExpressVPN logo and a promotional banner for their VPN service. Throughout the video, the environment remains consistent, with the web browser and article content being the primary focus.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker explaining that the URLs listed are for ".onion" sites accessible only through the Tor browser. He clarifies that the links won't work on a typical browser like Chrome and emphasizes the need to use Tor. The speaker has a casual tone. There's an instrumental track playing in the background throughout, which sounds like a moody and atmospheric electronic piece.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a series of webpages accessed through the Tor browser, emphasizing privacy and anonymity. It begins with a webpage discussing the benefits of browsing ProPublica's website via their onion site, highlighting its role in privacy and free speech. The scene transitions to Facebook's onion site, displaying a login page with the ExpressVPN logo and a promotional banner for a VPN service. The video then shifts to a DuckDuckGo search page, promoting privacy-focused search alternatives. Following this, a webpage titled "Network for Police Monitoring (Bangladesh)" appears, offering a form for submitting information anonymously. The final frame features the Hidden Wiki on an onion site, providing a link to a page about the site's main page. Throughout the video, the environment remains consistent, with the Tor browser window open and the focus on accessing various onion sites for privacy and anonymity.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with someone, presumably a male speaker, describing the "Tor browser" and mentioning "Facebook" and countries that restrict its use, adopting a casual, explanatory tone. He then directs attention to a "Hidden Wiki" section. All this happens over an underlying, mellow, electronic musical background.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer screen displaying a web browser with the URL 'about:blank' open, indicating that the browser is attempting to connect to a website. The browser's address bar shows the text 'Connecting...' as the page loads. The desktop background is white, and the taskbar at the bottom of the screen shows various application icons, including Google Chrome, File Explorer, and others. The system clock reads 11:19 PM, and the date is 1/16/2017. The scene transitions to a webpage titled 'The Hidden Wiki,' which lists various hidden services and their URLs, such as 'Welcome to the Hidden Wiki' and 'Editor's picks.' The page also includes a section titled 'Introduction Points' and a 'Volunteer' section, encouraging users to help by plugging other hidden service lists for links and performing dead services duties. The video then shows a series of webpages, including 'ExpressVPN,' 'DuckDuckGo,' and 'Facebook,' each with their respective URLs and content. The final frames display the 'The Hidden Wiki' page again, with the cursor hovering over the 'Main Page' link, indicating an attempt to navigate to the main page of the wiki. The video concludes with the cursor clicking on the 'Main Page' link, and the page begins to load, as indicated by the 'Connecting...' text in the browser's address bar.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the Hidden Wiki, cautioning about its links and potential content. He mentions blockchain, DuckDuckGo, and Facebook. He then returns to the Hidden Wiki, describing it as a one-stop shop with potentially unwanted content, but worth reading for information. Throughout this section, a consistent ambient electronic music plays, characterized by a somewhat ominous tone and synthesized instruments.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a webpage with a list of various services and resources available on the dark web. The initial frame highlights a section titled "Commercial Services," featuring links to services such as "CStore," "Gold & Diamonds," "Football Money," and "Digital Gangster," among others. The subsequent frames reveal additional sections, including "Anonymity & Security," "Hosting / Web / File / Image," "Blogs / Essays / Wikis," "Email / Messaging," and "Social Networks." Each section contains a list of links to different websites and services, such as "Tor Metrics," "Beneath VT," "KavkazCenter," "Jiskopedia," "Eros Ery Modziki," "Zilion 2.0," "Hotel Tor," "Tor Messaging," "BlackBook," "Galaxy 2," "Facebook," "Moneybook," "Truth & Light," "The Stock Insiders," "Hidden Answers," "The Intel Exchange," "Flashlight forum," "Anonymous BBS," "InserTor," and "Raid Forums." The video emphasizes the diverse range of services and resources available on the dark web, catering to various needs and interests, from financial transactions to social networking and information sharing. The webpage is presented in a simple, text-based format, with no images or multimedia elements, focusing solely on the links and descriptions of the services offered.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with male speech, listing items for sale such as skimmed cards, cloned credit cards, commercial services, fake IDs, and guns. The speaker also mentions fixed football games and hackers. This is followed by a brief musical interlude featuring a dark and tense electronic composition. The male speaker returns, referring to blogs, email, social networks, and "money book," suggesting that the items being discussed are available on the Dark Web. He concludes by saying there is "definitely a lot of stuff you can get into" and referencing WikiLeaks.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a webpage with a list of links categorized under various headings such as "WikiLeaks," "Other," "Audio-Web Radio / Streams," "Video / Movies / TV," "Books," and "Drugs." Each category contains links to different websites, some of which are related to whistleblowing, anonymous communication, and the Tor network. The "Drugs" section includes a warning about a marketplace named "Dream Market," which is labeled as a scam. The webpage has a simple, text-heavy layout with no visible images or multimedia elements. The cursor is seen moving across the screen, indicating user interaction with the webpage. The environment appears to be a digital interface, likely viewed on a computer or similar device, with a focus on providing access to various online resources and communities. The video does not show any people or physical objects, and the atmosphere is informational and utilitarian.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing a website, noting that it contains various content such as "reading nudes", and refers to it as a "Pandora box", listing further examples like "cat facts". The speaker continues noting that the site contains audio, video, books, and drugs, and mentions a "dream market". The speaker then changes topic and describes what else you may encounter on these sites, warning about "something illegal". In the background there's music playing throughout, it's electronic, slow and has a slightly eerie mood.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a webpage with a list of links categorized under various headings such as "Erotica," "Noncommercial," "Commercial," and "Animal Related." The links are accompanied by brief descriptions and some are marked with a Bitcoin symbol, indicating they are related to cryptocurrency transactions. The webpage also includes a section titled "Non-English," listing links in different languages like Belarusian, Finnish, French, German, Greek, Italian, Japanese, Spanish, and Portuguese. The cursor is seen moving across the screen, highlighting different links and sections. The environment appears to be a typical desktop setting with a web browser open, and the focus is on the content of the webpage rather than the physical surroundings. The video progresses through the webpage, showing the cursor interacting with the links and scrolling through the list, providing a detailed view of the content and its organization.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with music playing, characterized by a dark electronic vibe, with notable synth melodies and a somber mood. Then, a male speaker begins to talk, warning about the risks of clicking on anything erotic and potentially seeing things that can't be unseen. The speaker continues, referencing different language content and various types of available material, encouraging listeners to check it out at their own risk. As the speaking concludes, the music can still be heard, maintaining the somber, electronic atmosphere.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a computer screen displaying multiple browser tabs open, including Facebook, DuckDuckGo, and The Hidden Wiki. The user navigates to The Hidden Wiki, which features a list of recommended articles and a section for volunteers. The scene transitions to the Blockchain website, showcasing various statistics such as the number of transactions, total sent, relayed by, size, and weight. The user scrolls through the site, revealing more data including market cap, hash rate, and a graph depicting the number of transactions per day. The video then shifts to the DuckDuckGo homepage, highlighting its privacy-focused search engine. The user types a URL into the browser's address bar, indicating an intention to visit a specific website. Throughout the video, the focus remains on the computer screen and the user's interaction with the websites, with no visible people or physical environment beyond the digital interface.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with male speech, calmly suggesting getting a Bitcoin wallet and some Bitcoin to do transactions over the dark web. He adds to do some research on that and suggests there are plenty of resources to learn. He mentions DuckDuckGo and the .onion.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a computer screen displaying the DuckDuckGo search engine homepage, featuring its distinctive orange duck logo and the slogan "The search engine that doesn't track you." The user types "what can I do on tor browser" into the search bar, and the search results page appears, listing various articles and resources related to using the Tor browser. The user then clicks on a link to the Facebook login page, which is displayed in the browser. The Facebook page shows options to log in or sign up, with fields for email or phone number, password, first name, last name, mobile number or email, new password, and birthday. The user selects the gender option and clicks the "Create Account" button. The video concludes with the Facebook sign-up page still visible on the screen, indicating the user's intent to create a new account.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker talking about using a search engine, emphasizing that it is like Google. He wonders what one can do on a Tor browser and notes that using it won't get searches traced back to the user. He suggests that if one wants to search for something without being traced, using the dark web is the answer. The speaker then mentions accessing Facebook through the Tor browser. All the while, a piece of electronic music plays in the background, creating a mysterious and somewhat apprehensive atmosphere. The music features a repetitive, echoing rhythm and synthetic instruments.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a computer screen displaying multiple open tabs, including Facebook, Bitcoin Block Explorer, and The Hidden Wiki. The Facebook page is shown with options to log in or sign up, while The Hidden Wiki's main page is visible, featuring a list of recommended articles and a section for volunteers. The scene then transitions to a dramatic image of a large explosion with bright orange and yellow flames, accompanied by bold text that reads "WATCHING" in green letters with a red outline, set against the fiery backdrop. The video effectively contrasts the mundane online browsing experience with a sudden, intense visual of an explosion, creating a stark and attention-grabbing shift in tone.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker summarizing the advice given in the previous part of the show and concluding with an expression of gratitude to the audience. The tone is conversational and positive. A second male encourages the audience to stay safe, and a sound effect of glass shattering overlays the spoken word. Upbeat electronic music then abruptly begins.
